This date reflects the timing of public reporting and updates regarding the ongoing White House construction, emphasizing that the project has progressed beyond initial announcements.
The timing of the report coincides with the beginning of the actual structural demolition, making it a pivotal moment in the timeline of this unprecedented renovation.

keyTakeAways: The White House’s East Wing is undergoing massive demolition and reconstruction as part of President Donald Trump’s plan to build a new ballroom.
The new ballroom is estimated to cost $250 million, though earlier reports cited $200 million, and Trump claims it will be funded privately with no cost to taxpayers.
The ballroom will be approximately 90,000 square feet (8,360 square meters), with a seating capacity of 650–999 people, significantly larger than the current East Room, which seats about 200.

The East Wing, originally added in 1902, has housed the first lady’s offices since 1977 and includes a theatre and invitation office; it is built directly over the president’s underground emergency bunker.
The project began on Monday, October 21, 2025, and is the first structural change to the White House since 1948.
Despite the lack of formal approval from the National Capital Planning Commission (due to a nationwide government shutdown), construction proceeded.
Trump claims the project will not damage or touch the main White House building and will respect its historical integrity.
The project is being led by McCrery Architects, with construction by Clark Construction (Virginia) and engineering by AECOM (Dallas).
This is the first such structural change to the White House since 1948 and the first under a Trump administration.

summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump has announced the construction of a new 90,000-square-foot ballroom in the White House’s East Wing, marking the first structural change to the building since 1948. The project, estimated at $250 million and funded privately, began in October 2025 despite lacking formal approval from the National Capital Planning Commission due to a government shutdown. The East Wing, historically used for first lady offices and diplomatic events, will be demolished and rebuilt, with construction led by McCrery Architects, Clark Construction, and AECOM engineering. Trump emphasizes that the new ballroom will not damage the main White House and will respect its historical integrity, aiming to fulfill a long-standing presidential dream of hosting grand state events. The project is expected to be completed before the end of Trump’s term in 2029, with offices temporarily relocated and no demolition of the main building.
title: What to know about Trump’s plan to build $250m White House ballroom
